properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A 15 cm snowfall is expected tonight through Saturday midday. Hazards: 15 cm of snow Heavy snowfall rates up to 4 cm per hour at times Timing: Snow begins Friday evening and continues through Saturday late morning. The heaviest snow is expected early Saturday morning. Impacts: Poor visibility in heavy snowfall Poor road conditions due to quickly accumulating snow Discussion: Regional weather RADAR shows snow has begun or will begin soon in eastern Ontario. Steady light to moderate snow is likely through much of the late evening and overnight, with periods of heavy snow likely after 4 a.m. into Saturday morning. Total snowfall amounts near 15 cm are expected. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-02T18:00:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-02T02:08:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1882931162.2021

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A series of disturbances will move across the BC Interior over the next couple of days bringing significant snowfall to many mountain passes. Total snowfall accumulations of up to 50 cm are possible through Sunday morning for Kootenay Pass and Blueberry-Paulson Summit. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-02T15:45:48-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-01T23:45:48-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0490397150.2021

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Light rain will continue to impact the region this evening. However, the approach of another Pacific frontal system will intensify the rain to become heavy at times beginning overnight. The heavy rain will continue through Saturday then taper to showers Saturday night. Additional rainfall amounts near 75 mm are expected for the period. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of freezing rain expected this evening into tonight. Precipitation is forecast to begin as snow or ice pellets late this afternoon over parts of Southwestern Ontario before changing over to freezing rain by this evening. Freezing rain may be mixed with ice pellets or rain at times. This prolonged period of freezing rain is expected to bring up to 5 mm of ice accretion to many areas tonight. The freezing rain will transition back to snow overnight, with 5 to 10 cm of accumulation possible. This precipitation is associated with a low pressure system moving north from Texas which will track near the south shore of Lake Erie tonight. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Ice build-up may cause tree branches to break. Utility outages may occur. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-02T12:18:15-00:00

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in blowing snow are expected or occurring. An upper disturbance moving into northern Yukon will create strong east winds of 80 km/h near the Richardson Mountains tonight and Saturday. Poor visibility in blowing snow and extreme wind chill values between minus 40 and minus 50 are expected. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Road closures are possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-02T14:56:21-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall accumulations could possibly reach 15 cm. Locations: Central and Southern New Brunswick. Time span: Saturday morning until Saturday evening. Remarks: Current indications are that snow will begin Saturday morning with the heaviest snowfall expected over southern areas of the province along the Fundy coast. At this time some uncertainty still remains in the track of this weather system and a slight move to the north would shift the areas of heaviest snowfall to the north. Snowfall warnings are now in effect for Moncton and Southeast New Brunswick, Sussex - Kennebecasis Valley and Kings County, St. Stephen and Northern Charlotte County, Grand Manan and Coastal Charlotte County, Fundy National Park and Saint John and County. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-02T18:09:25-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-02T02:09:25-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1032734780.2021

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain possible tonight, along with snow. Snow will continue tonight. This snow may become mixed with ice pellets or periods of freezing rain late this evening and overnight. Some ice accretion is possible. Moderate to heavy snow will redevelop overnight with 5 to 10 cm of snowfall accumulation expected by the time the snow comes to an end early Saturday morning. At this point, the freezing rain is expected to be brief and patchy. However, freezing rain warnings may be needed if a longer lasting period of freezing rain is expected. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain possible tonight, along with a period of moderate snow. Precipitation will begin as snow early this evening. This snow may become mixed with ice pellets or periods of freezing rain tonight. Some minor ice accretion is possible. By late tonight, moderate to heavy snow will redevelop. 5 to 10 cm of accumulation is expected by the time the snow comes to an end early Saturday morning. This precipitation is associated with a low pressure system moving north from Texas which will track near the south shore of Lake Erie tonight. At this point, the freezing rain is expected to be brief and patchy. However, freezing rain warnings may be needed if the freezing rain looks to become longer lasting. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

Description: A Pacific frontal system will give snow to Williston and Highway 97 - Pine Pass tonight through Saturday. Additional 10 to 15 cm of snow can be expected by Saturday afternoon. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-02T14:55:14-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-01T22:55:14-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0657601711.2021
Area: Williston
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-02T15:46:34-00:00

Area: Trans-Canada Highway - Eagle Pass to Rogers Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A series of disturbances will move across the BC Interior tonight through Sunday bringing significant snowfall to many highway passes. Rogers Pass will see near 40 cm of snowfall from this afternoon through Sunday morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-02T15:46:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-01T23:46:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4039081831.2021
Area: Trans-Canada Highway - Eagle Pass to Rogers Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-02T18:08:16-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. Locations: Southern New Brunswick Time span: Saturday morning until Saturday evening. Remarks: The highest accumulations will occur over areas along the Fundy coast where locally higher snowfall amounts could approach 30 cm by the storm's end late Saturday evening. Furthermore, strong east to northeast winds gusting to 70 km/h may at times significantly reduce visibility in blowing snow. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-02T18:08:16-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-02T02:08:16-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3776267846.2021
Area: Sussex - Kennebecasis Valley and Kings County, Saint John and County, St. Stephen and Northern Charlotte County, Grand Manan and Coastal Charlotte County, Moncton and Southeast New Brunswick, Fundy National Park
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of freezing rain continues this evening. Freezing rain has developed and is expected to by mixed with ice pellets at times this evening. This period of freezing rain could bring measurable ice accretion up to 5 mm over some areas. The freezing rain is expected to transition to rain late this evening before finally transitioning back to snow overnight. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Ice build-up may cause tree branches to break. Utility outages may occur. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-02T12:59:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-02T01:39:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3045336539.2021
Area: Watford - Pinery Park - Eastern Lambton County, Sarnia - Petrolia - Western Lambton County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Light snow will end this evening as a weak weather disturbance passes through Manitoba. A more significant weather system will track through these same areas Saturday giving another 10 to 15 cm of snow before exiting into Ontario Saturday night. At this time it appears that the band of heavy snow will push through the communities of Lynn Lake and Brochet first. The heaviest snow will then pass north of the City of Thompson but south of the community of Tadoule Lake. This snowfall warning may be extended into the Gillam and Shamattawa regions at a later time. ### Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-02T13:29:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-01T21:29:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0785212767.2021
Area: Brochet, Tadoule Lake, Lynn Lake, Leaf Rapids, Pukatawagan, South Indian Lake and Amisk Prov. Park, Split Lake and York Landing, Thompson Thicket Portage and Pikwitonei, Nelson House
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Patchy freezing rain possible late this evening and overnight. Snow is transitioning to periods of rain or drizzle this evening. A period of freezing rain or freezing drizzle is possible later this evening and overnight. For areas near Lake Ontario, rain is expected with a much lower chance of any freezing rain. Some ice accretion is possible, but is generally expected to remain below 2 mm. Freezing rain is most likely away from Lake Ontario, particularly over the Oak Ridges Moraine. Precipitation will transition to snow by early Saturday morning. Freezing rain warnings are not anticipated at this time. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-02T16:59:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-02T02:13:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1839910210.2021
Area: City of Toronto, Pickering - Oshawa - Southern Durham Region, Cobourg - Colborne - Western Northumberland County, Burlington - Oakville
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Patchy freezing rain possible late this evening and tonight. Precipitation will begin as snow or ice pellets early this evening over areas north of Lake Ontario. A brief period of freezing rain or ice pellets is possible tonight. Any freezing rain is expected to transition to rain for areas near Lake Ontario while areas further north over the Oakridges moraine are likely to mix with snow. Some minimal ice accretion is possible, but is generally expected to remain below 2 mm. Precipitation will transition to snow by early Saturday morning. This precipitation is associated with a low pressure system moving north from Texas which will track near the south shore of Lake Erie tonight. Freezing rain warnings are not anticipated at this time. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-02T12:23:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-01T20:23:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3268782747.2021
Area: City of Toronto, Pickering - Oshawa - Southern Durham Region, Cobourg - Colborne - Western Northumberland County, Burlington - Oakville
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall accumulations of 15 cm or more possible Location: Prince Edward Island. Time span: Saturday afternoon until overnight Saturday night. Remarks: The snow will begin Saturday afternoon and taper off overnight Saturday. 15 cm of snow or more is possible especially over eastern areas of the island. At this time some uncertainty remains in the track of this weather system and a slight move to the north would shift the areas of heaviest snowfall westward. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-02T18:37:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-02T02:37:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2323976834.2021
Area: Kings County P.E.I., Queens County P.E.I., Prince County P.E.I.
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A few hours of freezing rain likely late this evening and overnight. Snow has changed over to a period of freezing rain or freezing drizzle. Periods of freezing rain or freezing drizzle are expected to continue into the overnight hours. Precipitation will transition back to snow overnight with an additional 2 to 4 cm snowfall accumulation possible by early Saturday morning. Ice accretion near 2 mm is possible on some surfaces. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-02T16:59:02-00:00

properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High concentration of pollutants are expected and will result in poor air quality, especially in urban areas where pollutant emissions are higher. High concentrations of pollutants are expected to diminish on Saturday. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. In Quebec, wood heating is the main source of fine particles that contribute to smog during winter. This activity generates the largest number of these particulates, more than industrial activities and transportation. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canada‚Äôs website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain possible tonight, along with snow. Snow may become mixed with ice pellets or periods of freezing rain or freezing drizzle late this evening and overnight. Some ice accretion is possible. Moderate to heavy snow will redevelop overnight with 5 to 10 cm of snowfall accumulation expected by the time the snow comes to an end early Saturday morning. At this point, the freezing rain is expected to be brief and patchy. However, freezing rain warnings may be needed if a longer lasting period of freezing rain is expected. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain continues this evening. Snow has changed to freezing rain or freezing drizzle over the area. Some ice accretion near 2 mm is possible, particularly for areas on top of the escarpment. Precipitation will transition to rain near midnight before changing to snow overnight, with a couple centimetres of accumulation possible. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A few hours of freezing rain likely this evening for areas away from Lake Ontario. Snow is changing over to a period of freezing rain or freezing drizzle for areas roughly north of Highway 401. For areas south of the 401, including cities like Mississauga, rain is expected with a much lower chance of any freezing rain. Some ice accretion near 2 mm is possible. Precipitation will transition back to snow overnight, with 2 to 4 cm of accumulation possible by early Saturday morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
